javadoc: AddressBasedLocation provides the ability to render and compare addresses (e.g., location table column). This may be necessary when working a mixture of address types (e.g., memory, stack, register, variable, external) with the need to render in a meaningful way. Generally, only memory addresses are meaningful to a user when rendered as a simple address (e.g., ram:00123456). While most address types are handled, VARIABLE addresses will only render as "<VARIABLE>". As such, this implementation should be extended if VARIABLE addresses will be encountered.

Construct a null location which generally corresponds to a unknown/bad

Construct a null location which generally corresponds to a unknown/bad

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Construction a location. The memory block name will never be included in
 string representation.

params.name: address
params.comment: address object (VARIABLE addresses should be avoided)

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Construct a location which corresponds to a reference TO address. String
 representation includes support for Offset References and allows control
 over inclusion of memory block name with memory addresses.

params.name: reference
params.comment: program reference (e.g., memory, stack, register, external)

params.name: showBlockName
params.comment:
ShowBlockName option for controlling inclusion of memory block 
 name with address rendering

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: Construct a location with a specific address and representation

methods.comment:
Compare this location's address with another location's given that they
 are both within the same address space.

name: AddressBasedLocation
comment:
AddressBasedLocation provides the ability to render and compare
 addresses (e.g., location table column). This may be necessary when working a
 mixture of address types (e.g., memory, stack, register, variable, external)
 with the need to render in a meaningful way. Generally, only memory addresses
 are meaningful to a user when rendered as a simple address (e.g.,
 ram:00123456). While most address types are handled, VARIABLE addresses will
 only render as "VARIABLE". As such, this implementation should be
 extended if VARIABLE addresses will be encountered.
